text.0: herbs that sprang up in time of old three ages earlier than the gods.
text.1: of these whose hue is brown will i declare the hundred powers and seven.
text.2: ye mothers have a hundred homes yea and a thousand are your growths.
text.3: do ye who have a thousand powers free this my patient from disease.
text.4: be glad and joyful in the plants both blossoming and bearing fruit.
text.5: plants that will lead us to success like mares who conquer in the race.
text.6: plants by this name i speak to you mothers to you the goddesses.
text.7: steed cow and garment may i win win back thy very self o man.
text.8: the holy fig tree is your home your mansion is the parna tree.
text.9: winners of cattle shali ye be if ye regain for me this man.
text.10: he who hath store of herbs at hand like kings amid a crowd of men.
text.11: physician is that sages name fiendslayer chaser of disease.
text.12: herbs rich in soma rich in steeds in nourishments in strengthening power.
text.13: all these have i provided here that this man may be whole again.
text.14: the healing virtues of the plants stream forth like cattle from the stall.
text.15: plants that shall win me store of wealth and save thy vital breath o man.
text.16: reliever is your mothers name and hence restorers are ye called.
text.17: rivers are ye with wings that fly keep far whatever brings disease.
text.18: over all fences have they passed as steals a thief into the fold.
text.19: the plants have driven from the frame whatever malady was there.
text.20: when bringing back the vanished strength i hold these herbs within my hand.
text.21: the spirit of disease departs ere he can seize upon the life.
text.22: he through whose frame o plants ye creep member by member joint by joint.
text.23: from him ye drive away disease like some strong arbiter of strife.
text.24: fly spirit of disease begone with the blue jay and kingfisher.
text.25: fly with the winds impetuousspeed vanish together with the storm.
text.26: help every one the other lend assistance each of you to each.
text.27: all of you be accordant give furtherance to this speech of mine.
text.28: let fruitful plants and fruitless those that blossom and the blossomless.
text.29: urged onward by bṛhaspati release us from our pain and grief.
text.30: release me from the curses plague and woe that comes from varuṇa.
text.31: free me from yamas fetter from sin and offence against the gods.
text.32: what time descending from the sky the plants flew earthward thus they spake.
text.33: no evil shall befall the man whom while he liveth we pervade.
text.34: of all the many plants whose king is soma plants of hundred forms.
text.35: thou art the plant most excellent prompt to the wish sweet to the heart.
text.36: o all ye various herbs whose king is soma that oerspread the earth.
text.37: urged onward by bṛhaspati combine your virtue in this plant.
text.38: unharmed be he who digs you up unharmed the man for whom i dig.
text.39: and let no malady attack biped or quadruped of ours.
text.40: all plants that hear this speech and those that have departed far away.
text.41: come all assembled and confer your healing power upon this herb.
text.42: with soma as their sovran lord the plants hold colloquy and say.
text.43: o king we save from death the man whose cure a brahman undertakes.
text.44: most excellent of all art thou o plant thy vassals are the trees.
text.45: let him be subject to our power the man who seeks to injure us.
